courseDescription: Students will finish this course with the ability to demonstrate competency in and teach fundamental camping skills, including backpacking, cooking, travel techniques, Leave No Trace skills, and associated safety skills.  Additionally, students will demonstrate an increased understanding of issues related to the administration of federally-managed public lands, such as those used in this class, as they relate to recreation and other uses.  An overnight field tip is required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing issues related to the administration of federally-managed public lands
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and managing issues related to the administration of federally-managed public lands
Planning and executing an overnight field trip
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and leading an overnight field trip
Teaching and demonstrating backpacking and camping skills

courseDescription: This course will examine leisure and its relationship to human behavior from historical and contemporary perspectives.  The course will explore fundamental principles, theories, and philosophies of recreation, play, and leisure and how they relate to health and wellness, quality of life, personal identity, work, the economy, and social institutions. The role of leisure in one’s life will be examined in depth with a focus on positive and negative leisure behaviors, trends in world culture, and how societal factors influence leisure behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on historical and contemporary leisure trends
Analysis of societal factors influencing leisure behavior
Understanding of principles, theories, and philosophies of recreation, play, and leisure
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and debate leisure trends and behaviors
Understanding of diverse leisure behaviors in world cultures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of positive and negative leisure behaviors
Ability to analyze the impact of leisure on health, wellness, and quality of life
Evaluation of the economic and societal impacts of leisure
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of the role of leisure in personal and professional identity
Ability to guide others in optimizing leisure for overall wellness and quality of life

courseTitle: Program Planning and Development in Parks, Recreation, and Tourism
courseDescription: This course is designed to help students understand and develop their program planning and development skills. Theories and techniques in relation to programs in parks, recreation organizations, and hospitality and tourism businesses are explored. The course will examine the planning process, including needs assessment, risk assessment, staffing, marketing, budgeting, and implementation.

courseTitle: Introduction to Park and Recreation Management
courseDescription: This course introduces students to the field of park and recreation management, including public, non-profit, and private/commercial service delivery organizations. Career opportunities in each of these sectors will also be explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public, non-profit, and private/commercial service delivery organizations
Knowledge of career opportunities in park and recreation management sectors
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to present and explain career opportunities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in park and recreation management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and application of management principles
Leadership in park and recreation settings

courseDescription: This course is designed to present an introduction to the tourism industry.  Emphasis is placed on historical and technological development within tourism, the different components of the industry (transportation, accommodations, attractions, events), and career opportunities in tourism, events, and hospitality.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of historical and technological development in tourism
Knowledge of different components of tourism industry including transportation, accommodations, attractions, events
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate effectively with various stakeholders in the tourism, events, and hospitality industry
Ability to present career opportunities in the tourism, events, and hospitality industry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the evolution of tourism industry
Assessment of different components of the tourism industry
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to identify and seize career opportunities in tourism, events, and hospitality industry
Capability to manage different components of the tourism industry

courseTitle: Diversity in Parks, Recreation and Tourism
courseDescription: This course is designed as an introduction to the responsibilities of public, private, and commercial leisure service delivery systems in relation to their diverse constituents. The objective of this course is to increase students’ awareness and knowledge of the needs of members of ethnic and racial groups, people of diverse socioeconomic status, women, older adults, members of the LGBTQIA+ community, and people with disabilities. Moreover, the course introduces students to concepts and factors that influence the delivery of recreation and tourism services to diverse populations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public, private, and commercial leisure service delivery systems
Knowledge of recreation and tourism services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse socioeconomic, racial and ethnic groups
Understanding and respect for the LGBTQIA+ community
Understanding and empathy for people with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing factors that influence the delivery of services to diverse populations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and providing services to diverse populations

courseDescription: This course is designed to help students develop recreation facilitation and leadership skills. The course will focus on leadership theories, recreation leadership techniques, and group dynamics. Students will practice group leadership techniques through in-class activities and community engaged learning.

This course examines personnel, financial and organizational management principles, practices, and policies related to the recreation industry. The course explores general personnel management, organizational management, and the budget process. Students will learn about revenue sources, budget formats, and managing full-time, part-time, and seasonal personnel.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with full-time, part-time, and seasonal personnel
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in personnel and organizational management

courseDescription: This course teaches the knowledge and skills needed to navigate lodging operations in the hospitality industry and provides students with a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles and practices associated with the successful operation of lodging facilities.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within the hospitality industry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of lodging facility performance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for managing lodging operations

courseDescription: Agency field placement is required of all students in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies. Seminar will include resume and cover letter writing skills, internship requirements, agency placement referrals, and interviewing techniques.

Supervised agency placement is required of all students in the Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies program.  Placement must fulfill all professionally appropriate certification standards.  Minimum of 400 clock hours. Students must have an overall GPA of 2.00 and a major GPA of 2.00 at the start of the internship.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adherence to professional standards and regulations

courseTitle: Practicum in Parks, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Selected field-based experiences in a park, recreation and tourism service setting. Minimum of 200 clock hours.
Technical and Digital Skills: Practical understanding of park, recreation and tourism services
Knowledge of safety and compliance regulations

courseDescription: This course addresses outdoor recreation and natural management using a recreation ecology framework. Physical and social impacts resulting from outdoor recreation in parks and protected areas will be discussed, as well as visitor use management strategies to address those impacts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessment of physical impacts from outdoor recreation
Analysis of social impacts from outdoor recreation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engagement with park visitors and community stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Development of outdoor recreation management strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in park and protected area management
Implementation and enforcement of visitor use strategies

courseDescription: This course is designed to increase knowledge, skills, techniques, policies and procedures related to outdoor recreation. Students are required to participate in outdoor recreation experiences through the Outdoor Adventure Program and on their own.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of outdoor policies and procedures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing outdoor recreation experiences

courseDescription: This course is designed to examine the history, development, and trends in outdoor leadership and environmental education, including the development of curriculum concepts that foster an environmentally literate citizenry. Leadership and teaching techniques for successful utilization of the outdoors as a classroom will be explored. Students are required to participate in outdoor recreation experiences through the Outdoor Adventure Program and on their own.
Technical and Digital Skills: Planning and executing outdoor recreational activities
Knowledge of outdoor leadership history and trends

courseDescription: This course will cover organization and administration of camp programs and facilities including history, trends, staffing, client needs, finance, marketing, accreditation, research and legal issues. Primary emphasis will be on organized camp programs and their impact on youth and society.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Impact evaluation on youth and society

courseDescription: This course explores theories and concepts related to marketing and sales within successful service-oriented hospitality and tourism businesses. Course topics include marketing and sales planning, techniques, strategies, and management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of hospitality and tourism business strategies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with customers in the hospitality industry
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in hospitality and tourism businesses
Organizational skills for marketing and sales planning

courseDescription: This course explores the meaning and practice of leadership and management in the hospitality and tourism industry. The course links theoretical concepts to the application of best practice in various aspects of administration. Students will also learn about current trends, research, and national and international case studies
Technical and Digital Skills: Hospitality and tourism management software proficiency
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Research and analysis of hospitality trends

courseDescription: This course is designed to equip students with a practical understanding of the principles involved in the revenue management of hospitality businesses. By blending theoretical concepts with real-world applications, students will learn how to ethically apply these techniques to enhance business outcomes in a dynamic industry. The Certification in Hotel Industry Analytics (CHIA), which is the only hotel-related certification that recognizes the skill and knowledge that these professionals have, is embedded in this course to boost the career prospects of students.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of theoretical concepts to real-world scenarios
Preparation for Certification in Hotel Industry Analytics (CHIA)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ethical application of revenue management techniques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of revenue management techniques to enhance business outcomes

courseTitle: Sustainable Management in Parks, Recreation, and Tourism
courseDescription: This course examines the principles and practices of sustainable management within park, recreation, and tourism settings. The course explores the complexities of sustainable management and best practices for achieving economic, environmental, social, and cultural sustainability.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of best practices for economic, environmental, social, and cultural sustainability
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of sustainable management practices
Collaboration within park, recreation, and tourism settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving within the context of sustainable management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing sustainable initiatives within park, recreation, and tourism settings

courseTitle: Evaluation in Parks, Recreation, and Tourism
courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to provide students with basic knowledge in research and evaluation within the park, recreation and tourism field. Specific focus is placed on applying research and evaluation concepts through a research or evaluation project within the field.  Topics include evaluation criteria development, quantitative and qualitative research methods, and utilizing study results to make practical recommendations for park, recreation, and tourism organizations.  This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Utilizing study results to make practical recommendations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and conducting research or evaluation project

courseDescription: This course advances students’ knowledge of the marketing, planning, and management of festivals, meetings and conventions, and special events in tourism destinations. Students will learn strategies for successfully planning, marketing, organizing, and implementing a variety of events.

courseTitle: Topics in Parks, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: This course provides an opportunity for in-depth study of selected topics in the variety of areas comprising parks, recreation and tourism studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data collection and analysis in tourism industry

courseDescription: Individualized instruction to include research, specialized studies, or other scholarly writing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Specialized knowledge in chosen study area

courseTitle: Research Problems in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Practice in the use of statistical and analytical techniques in solving problems in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies; supervised student research.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies

courseTitle: Contemporary Issues in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: This course is designed to increase the student's ability to critically analyze and discuss the contemporary issues and trends in parks, recreation and tourism. This course will require students to describe, evaluate, and critique the current research in the field; evaluate the future trajectory of park, recreation and tourism studies; and assess both personal and professional philosophies to elucidate his/her role as an advanced-level practitioner in parks, recreation or tourism industry.

courseTitle: Internship in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Designed to provide detailed practical experience (400 clock hours) in a park, recreation or tourism field setting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Practical knowledge of park, recreation or tourism operations
Use of digital tools for park and recreation management
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting with diverse groups of people
Clear and concise communication in a field setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing park or tourism site management data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in a park, recreation or tourism setting

courseTitle: Topics in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Selected topic courses in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of park and recreation management software
Basic digital marketing for tourism promotion
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with park visitors and tourists
Customer service in the tourism industry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Conflict resolution in park and recreation settings
Analysis of tourism trends and patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in park and recreation environments

courseTitle: Independent Study in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Investigations in park, recreation, and tourism studies. Problems approved in advance are investigated under the supervision of the faculty advisor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research methodology in park, recreation, and tourism
Use of digital tools for data collection and analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of problems in park, recreation, and tourism

courseTitle: Thesis Research in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Students work independently with a faculty member to conduct research for their thesis on a topic related to Park, Recreation, and Tourism Studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Usage of research software and databases

courseTitle: Thesis in Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies
courseDescription: Students work independently with a faculty member to complete their thesis on a topic related to Park, Recreation and Tourism Studies.

This course explores the complexities and evolution of tourism consumer behavior from a multidisciplinary perspective. Choosing, buying and consuming tourism/travel products and services includes a range of psycho-social processes, individual and environmental influences, motivations, and meanings that researchers and managers of national parks and tourism destinations should take into account when evaluating the tourism experience. This course provides an overview of such processes and influences and explains the basic and advanced concepts and theories that underlie tourist decision-making and behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of tourism/travel products and services
Assessment of individual and environmental influences
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with national parks and tourism destination managers
Understanding and interpreting tourist motivations and meanings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying basic and advanced concepts and theories underlining tourist decision-making and behavior
Developing strategies based on consumer behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in evaluating and enhancing tourism experiences

courseTitle: Advanced Leisure Theories and their Applications
courseDescription: The course examines the concepts, theories and philosophies related to outdoor recreation, travel and tourism, and community recreation. Discussion will focus on the application of social science theories to the study of leisure, parks, recreation and tourism.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital tools for tourism and community recreation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in leisure and tourism contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of social science theories to leisure studies
Critical analysis of leisure, park, recreation and tourism concepts

courseDescription: This course targets research related to outdoor recreation in parks and open spaces. Empirical studies investigating sense of place, motivations for outdoor recreation, carrying capacity, crowding, recreation opportunity spectrum, and other sensitive issues will be covered. The course will also provide a historical overview of social sciences in outdoor recreation, and the principles guiding park management.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Historical analysis of social sciences in outdoor recreation
Management of parks and open spaces

courseDescription: This course provides preparation for upper-level recreation administration. National standards for managerial, administrative and executive decision-making for parks and recreation professionals will be discussed, in addition to practical knowledge and current real-world skills necessary in today's changing park and recreation environment. The course is designed to prepare professionals to sit for the Certified Park and Recreation Professionals (CPRP) or Certified Park and Recreation Executive (CPRE) exam.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of national standards for parks and recreation
Understanding of current trends in park and recreation environment
Preparation for Certified Park and Recreation Professionals (CPRP) or Certified Park and Recreation Executive (CPRE) exams
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of park and recreation standards
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in park and recreation environment
Managerial skills for parks and recreation professionals

courseDescription: This course examines the planning, development and management of the tourism industry with regard to economic, social, cultural and environmental sustainability. Current theory and research in the field of sustainable tourism will also be explored in order for students to develop a critical perspective on sustainable tourism development.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within the tourism industry
Promotion of cultural awareness and respect
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of sustainable tourism research
Evaluation of sustainability in the tourism industry

courseTitle: Grant Writing for Parks and Recreation
courseDescription: Grant writing is an essential skill for the park and recreation professional. This course examines the grant writing process. This includes, but is not limited to, The Office of Research, the ODU Research Foundation, budgeting, human subjects, and partnerships. Students will be expected to submit a grant application by the end of the course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Writing clear and persuasive grant proposals

courseDescription: The Positive Youth Development (PYD) movement has been greatly influenced by sport and recreation. With the recent increase of diabetes, obesity, sedentary lifestyles, and risky behaviors among youth, sport and recreation professionals are charged to help alleviate these societal issues. More specifically, practitioners need to target the socio-emotional needs of our youth through the sport and recreation experience. By using class lectures, technology, video, and self-directed research, students will explore research, theory, practice, and techniques of structuring positive experiences for youth. This course includes the examination of theories on youth development, behavior management, motivation, resiliency, and social skills as they relate to the sport and recreation experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of sport and recreation theories
Understanding and application of behavior management techniques
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instruction and guidance of youth in sport and recreation experiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and managing risky behaviors among youth
Analysis and interpretation of youth development research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading youth in sport and recreation experiences

courseDescription: This course explores the complexities and evolution of tourism consumer behavior from a multidisciplinary perspective. Choosing, buying and consuming tourism/travel products and services includes a range of psycho-social processes, individual and environmental influences, motivations, and meanings that researchers and managers of national parks and tourism destinations should take into account when evaluating the tourism experience. This course provides an overview of such processes and influences and explains the basic and advanced concepts and theories that underlie tourist decision-making and behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying multidisciplinary research methods
Implementing psycho-social processes in tourist decision-making
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding individual and environmental influences on tourist behavior
Communicating effectively with national park managers and tourism destination managers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and analyzing motivations and meanings behind tourist behavior
Applying basic and advanced concepts and theories in real-world tourism contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and evaluating the tourism experience

courseTitle: Advanced Leisure Theories and their Applications
courseDescription: The course examines the concepts, theories and philosophies related to outdoor recreation, travel and tourism, and community recreation. Discussion will focus on the application of social science theories to the study of leisure, parks, recreation and tourism.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching and analyzing outdoor recreation, travel and tourism, and community recreation theories and philosophies
Application of theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios in leisure, parks, recreation and tourism
Understanding and use of social science theories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and presentation of leisure theories
Collaborative discussion on application of theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of leisure, parks, recreation and tourism concepts
Critical evaluation and application of social science theories
Problem-solving in outdoor recreation, travel and tourism, and community recreation contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on leisure theories and their applications
Strategic application of theories to practical scenarios

courseDescription: This course targets the pursued and needed research of outdoor recreation in parks and open space. Empirical studies investigating areas such as: sense of place, motivations for outdoor recreation, carrying capacity, crowding, recreation opportunity spectrum, and other sensitive issues will be covered. The course will also include an historical overview of social sciences in outdoor recreation. The course will also cover principles to guide park management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Historical analysis of social sciences in outdoor recreation
Understanding of principles for park management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Handling sensitive issues in outdoor recreation

courseDescription: This course provides preparation for upper-level recreation administration. National standards for managerial, administrative and executive decision-making for parks and recreation professionals will be discussed, in addition to practical knowledge and current real-world skills necessary in today's changing park and recreation environment. The course is designed to prepare professionals to sit for the Certified Park and Recreation Professionals (CPRP) or Certified Park and Recreation Executive (CPRE) exam.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of national standards for managerial, administrative and executive decision-making
Understanding of Certified Park and Recreation Professionals (CPRP) or Certified Park and Recreation Executive (CPRE) exam content
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with park and recreation professionals
Ability to discuss and explain national standards and practical knowledge
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision-making for parks and recreation management
Analysis and application of national standards and professional exams
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managerial skills for park and recreation administration
Ability to adapt to changing park and recreation environment

courseDescription: This course examines the planning, development and management of the tourism industry with regard to economic, social, cultural and environmental sustainability. Current theory and research in the field of sustainable tourism will also be explored in order for students to develop a critical perspective on sustainable tourism development.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of economic, social, cultural and environmental sustainability in tourism
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critical discussion of sustainable tourism theories
Effective communication of research findings in sustainable tourism
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of current theories and research in sustainable tourism
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing sustainable tourism initiatives

courseDescription: The Positive Youth Development (PYD) movement has been greatly influenced by sport and recreation. With the recent increase of diabetes, obesity, sedentary lifestyles, and risky behaviors among youth, sport and recreation professionals are charged to help alleviate these societal issues. More specifically, practitioners need to target the socio-emotional needs of our youth through the sport and recreation experience. By using class lectures, technology, video, and self-directed research, students will explore research, theory, practice, and techniques of structuring positive experiences for youth. This course includes the examination of theories on youth development, behavior management, motivation, resiliency, and social skills as they relate to the sport and recreation experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of technology for teaching and research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing socio-emotional needs of youth
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Research and analysis of youth development theories
Addressing societal issues (obesity, sedentary lifestyles, risky behaviors) through recreation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Structuring and managing sports and recreation experiences
Promoting youth resiliency and social skills
